Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Wave Coupling and its Role in the Momentum and Energy Budget of the Middle Atmosphere
Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is to better understand wave coupling mechanisms and their role in the dynamics of the Earth's middle atmosphere. The investigators will examine the tidal/planetary wave, tidal/gravity wave and planetary/gravity wave couplings in the Mesosphere and Lower Thermosphere (MLT) region of the atmosphere by employing data from a complementary general circulation model, the extended Canadian Middle Atmospheric Model (CMAM). They will use modeled data (including temperature, winds, gravity wave forcing) over an annual cycle from the extended CMAM, a full, three-dimensional, self-consistent, and spectral general circulation model from the Earth's surface to about 210 km, to study the physical mechanisms of the interaction processes in tidal/planetary wave and tidal/gravity wave and their role in the momentum budget of the atmospheric tides. They will also employ the one-year modeled data from the extended CMAM (such as winds, geopotential height, and gravity wave forcing) to study the possible consequence of the planetary/gravity wave coupling - generation of large-scale planetary waves in the upper mesosphere and lower thermosphere region of the Earth's atmosphere. Further understanding of the upward propagation and latitudinal-propagation of the planetary waves in the upper mesosphere and lower thermosphere will be also achieved. The study will lead to a better understanding of the processes that govern the coupling, energetics and dynamics of the middle and upper atmosphere. The project also addresses the complexity of nonlinearity, a crucial element that needs to be understood within the space atmosphere interaction region (SAIR) in order to better predict 'space weather'. Furthermore, the work is highly relevant to the efforts of the international Climate and Weather of the Sun-Earth System (CAWSES) research community. The project supports efforts to expand atmospheric dynamics research in Kentucky through support of a graduate research assistant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is to better understand wave dynamics (including atmospheric tides, planetary waves, and gravity waves) in the middle and upper atmosphere, particularly, how they interact with each other and with the background flow. These waves are important because they can propagate upwards and affect the day-to-day variability of the weather in space. Space weather can significantly impact the electric power industry, aviation, GPS applications, communication systems, satellites, and space flight. As the modern world becomes more and more dependent on technologies that are vulnerable to changes in the near-Earth environment, the need for accurate forecasting space weather only increases. However, accurate space weather forecasting requires a better understanding of the temporal and spatial variability of these waves from the lower atmosphere.

    Using state-of-art global general circulation models and satellite observations, we investigated how tide/tide and tide/planetary wave interaction from the lower atmosphere can affect feature and composition changes in the ionosphere and thermosphere, such as midnight temperature maximum (MTM), total electron content (TEC), F2 region peak electron density etc. Planetary waves and gravity wave interact with the mean flow and can also cause localized solar cycle response in the lower atmosphere. To rigorously understand the physical mechanisms behind their interactions, more robust methodology needs to be developed other than correlation analysis. Results from this project also demonstrate that we need to further improve our understanding on the basic flow of our atmosphere, which ultimately affect wave propagation and dissipation. The project addresses the complexity of nonlinearity, a crucial element need to be understood within the space-atmosphere interaction region in order to better predict space weather.

    This award has provided opportunities and support to train and educate undergraduate and graduate students at University of Louisville, Kentucky in aeronomy/atmospheric science/space physics. This area of research is new to University of Louisville and to Kentucky (an EPSCoR state). The PI is a female assistant professor in the newly established atmospheric science program at University of Louisville. The only other such program in Kentucky is in the geography department at Western Kentucky University. As hoped, the Louisville program is attracting minorities and women: our first graduate was a minority (African- American) and approximately half of our students are female. Research projects like this one have high visibility and high impact in this setting. Undergraduate and graduate students have showcased their research at national conferences a dozen times owning to this award and 6 peer-reviewed papers are published in scientific journals and 1 more is submitted and currently under-revision.
